cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.

doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.

The Japewe. Government has placed an irgent order in Glasgow for 30 locomotiven. (leuter.)
The North Sea Commissioners resumed their sittings today. The parties submitted their coriclusions, both strougly adhering to their original statements. (Reuter.
The North Sea Commission of Enquiry has heard the conclusions of counsel for England and for Russia
The conclusions of the English counsel maintain the absence of torpe-to-boats and declan the Russian fire to have been unjustified.

The conclusions of the Russian counsel deciure that military reasons justified the fin of the Russian ships. Russia, however, agree to pay an indemnity, which would be fixed by the Hague Tribunal. ...

div.head: "DOWN WITH THE AUTOCRACY." DEMONSTRATION AT A THEATRE.

div.p: There was # demonstration in the Mal Theatre bere last night, men crying "Down with the autocracy and making use of persona învectives against the Tur. The demonstrators were finally ejected, and the performance i continued.

div.head: AMERICAN ARBITRATION. THE PRESIDENT AND SENATE.

div.p: President Roosevelt and the Senate have reached ad acute state of disagreement concerning the arbitration treaties which Mr. Hay has laboriously concluded with Japan, Great Britain, and syemal other European Powers. In spite of strong pressure on the part of Mr. Rooreveit, the Senate inserted an amendment in the treaties Securg to it the right to intervene belore any question is submittest w arbitration. In consequence, Mr. Roosevelt has resolved to drop the treaties altogether,
Public opinion, apparently, endorsey the action of the Suuate. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE HUNGARIAN CRISIS. AN HISTORICAL EVENT:

div.p: The Emperor yesterday received Herr Kos. suth in connection with the Hungarian crisis. It was a notable bistorical event as it was his first entrance to the Palace to my homage to the Emperor who bad condemned his father to death. (Reuter.)

div.head: GERMANY AND ABYSSINIA. MISSION AT ADIS ABEBA.

div.p: The German mission, mentioned on the 6th December, has been received by the Emperor Menelik at Adis Abeba. The mission will remain there for 20 days. .. (Renter.

div.head: Tux AMERICAN STEAM
div.p: Yacur "Aloedo," lir. G. W. C. Drexel, owner, has arrived from

div.head: FIELD DAY--
div.p: A tactical field day will be held at ibhussieh for the Cairo garrison on Thurs next

div.head: The KHEDIVE'-
div.p: Yacht the "Mahroussa," which arrived in the Clyde a firtnight ago, i. uw moored close to. Meurs. Inglis' yard at Penthouse, where the alterations will be carried out.

div.head: THE ALEXANDRIA SCANDAL. -
div.p: The Italian Consular Court of Alexandria pronounced judgment yesterday in the divorce proceedings instituted by Mr. Ninci. Particulars will be found on page 1.

div.head: The POWELL-COTON EXPEDITION
div.p: has left the Nile and arrived at the Zubesi. Accurd. Jing to the latest advices received from Major
Powell Cotton he has started for an unexplored section of the Congo Stata in -carch of the wlata rhinoceros.

div.head: PHE AMERICAN COLLEGE, BEYROUT. —
div.p: "An Eye witness" sends us details of some strange events, which are alleged to have transpired at the American College at Beyrout on the 7th and sth inst. As our orrespondent is anony mous we cannot publish his statements.

div.head: CATTLE PLAQUE..
div.p: During the week ending Satunlay last, 7 deaths from bovine typhus were reported throughout Egypt. During the corresponding week in 1904 5,949 deaths were notified. Since the beginning of the epidemic the total number of deaths is 146 710.

div.head: NEW CATHEDRAL FOR CAIRO.-
div.p: The scheme for the erection of a Maronite Cathedral at Cairo bas taken definite shape and L E. 10,000 has already been subscribed. Mgr. Darian, the Maronite Archbish p. Chakour Pasha, Abdullah Bey Sfer, and many other Syrian notables, are heartily supporting the scheme.

div.p: We do not had our strax for the responsable opinions expreso 1 ty car correspondessta, lant wa wimb, spirit of fair pla to all, to purit - within a scary limita fres d ansion.

div.head: A RACE OF ARTIS IS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir, I send a few of the smaller stones from the desert, which I think you have not seen, and for which I hope I may claim your adiniration. What, sir, would not gott or I give for that touch of hand and truth of eye ! Look at the wonderful skill with I which they have been carved, repeating again

and again the same idea, but almost always with the distinctive touch of the individual worker,--just as in the pretty attractive cloth I word of the Kabyle women, the pattern is not copied or mechanically repeated, but each worker follows an instinct of her own. And so it was with this old stone race. With some exceptions, some types ronghly executed-perhaps of the earlier time, for it! was over an immense space of time that they worked, -- and some few that merely repro dnced the conventional pattern, the mass of the stones bear constant witness to the free play of band and imagination. What gifts this desert people bad i One may donbt--and I am not forgetting the story of Greece, which wa- different in its kind if the world has ever yet produced a race with such an artistic sense 1-o widely distributed--perhaps in Japan 'you have had the nearest approach to it. In the artistic fancies of both ruces - the love of the quaint and grotesque-the mixture of human and demon-yet with a certain self-restraint, the half extravagance kept within the limits of sobriety--you feel as if there were common elements--as if the two races had shared some of the same gifts. I should like to send a tow examples to Tokio for our Japanese friends to pass judgment upon.

And now, sir, how goes it with my friends, the learned babes 1 Have they mended their little wayward fashions, and grown in wisdom and stature! Or is A.B.C. still the same sal trial, as it was, to their rebel souls 1 Do they Ixtill pont and sulk in their eyrtier? Do they still cry "can't, shan't, won't” while the little fists are doubled up in the little eyes and the little
feet stawp upon the flxer? Was there ever sich Ja hullabaloo and piece of work in the nursery
all about learning A.B.C., which sooner or later must be learned. There is no prissible escape from it. No amount of shan't and won't

can help them. Their fate is inexorably I written. And never was there a prettier, pleasanter, more attractive A.B.C. for a babe to learn--an A.B.C. that sh-uld never have cost a tear oz a whimper! And as soon as they once humble the haughty little souls- just a touch wanted of the penitent's redeeming grace--and set themselves with goodwill to the task, what delight they will find in it, what revelations are waiting for them! But I must not take up too much of your space. At
Rome, Trieste, Athens, and again at AlexJandria, I found after some little hunting plenty

of traces of the same race. The stone was I much less favorable, ant the work consequently much rougher ; but the lealing types were the same. Some day we ought to be able to trace with considerable exnotness the march of this great people--for really great they | were. You cannot live amongst their work, and with hold your admiration from them.I am, eto,
div.byline: AUBEBON HERBERT. Tewfik Palace Hotel, Helouan,

div.head: ROYAL VISIT TO KHARTOUM.
REVIEW OF TROOPS.
div.p: A review of all the troops in the station I was held this morning on the parade ground at| Khartoum. At 8 o'clock H.R.H. the Duchess of Connanght, with the Princesses, accompanied by Lady Wingate, arrived ina landau at the Royal| stand. A few minntes later H.R. H. the Duke, | accompanied by H.E. the Sirlar and Governor| General, General Sir J. Maxwell, and the staff, followed on the parade-ground, and the Royal Standard was at once boisted near the enclosure. | After the inspection, the troops began to file past his H.R.H., performing the various evolutions, the Rifle Brigade being specially smart and showing they had marched over Sudan sands once before. The cavalry, and notably the artillery, appear to bave been I quite up to the mark, and H.R.H. was pleased to express his entire satisfaction with the bearing of the troops and the evolutions effected.

I learn that the Duke of Connaught expressed the opinion that trousers for the native troups, shaped Zouave fashion, would perhaps be more suitable for this climate than the ordinary trou-ers now in use.
In the after on, the Royal party, accompanied by the whole staff, crossed over on a visit to Omdurman.

In the evening there was a military tattoo in front of Government baildings, at which the Royal party were present. Bimbashi Franklin, director of mu-io, was bonored with a few words of thanks from H. R. H. for his services on the occasion. ROYAL PARTY AT DIVINE SERVICE.
Khartoum, February 5.
The Royal party attended divine service this morning in the temporary church room in the Palace.

div.head: VISIT TO GORDON COLLEGE.
div.p: T. R. H. the Duke and Duchess of Con. naught, with the Princesses, and accompanied by H. E. the Governor General, Lady Wingate, and snite, visited Gordon College to-day and then drove round the town of Khartoum. The natives turned out and gave the Royal party a hearty greeting. The annual regatta took | place in the afternoon in front of the Palace, and at 10.30 p.m. the Royal party left for the North. I may mention that the police arrange ments throughout the Royal visit were perfect.

div.head: ASSOUAN DAM VISITED.
div.p: The Dake and Duchess of Connaught arriv. ed at Assouan this moruing and will visit the dam in the afternoon accompanied by Sir Willinn Garstin, Mr. A. L. Webb, Mr. Clowes, and Mr. Macdonald.
The R val party will leave Luxor on Thursday by a special train leaving at 6.50 p.m. which will bring them to Cairo at 9.10 a.m. ou Friday.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: Today H. H. the Khedive visited the Mosque at Koubbeh for prayer on the opening of Kourban Beyram. Salvoes of 21 guns were fired from the Citadel and at Abbassieh on the arrival and departure of his Highness.

Yesterday afternoon, his Highness received Ally Pasha Yaghen, Governor of Cairo, and all the principal functionaries or notables who received promotion or decorations on the occasion of the anniversary of H. H.'s accession.

div.head: GENERAL STOESSEL AT SUEZ.
div.p: The Messageries Maritimes 8.8. “Australien," by which Gen. Stoessel is a passenger, is due to arrive at Suez to-morrow at 10 a.m.

div.head: PLAGUE ON STEAMER.
div.p: The Austrian Lloyd 8.S. "Imperator," from Bombay, arrived at Suez yesterday. Owing to her having landed a case of plagne at Aden, she was put in quarantine at this port, and after being disinfected entered the Canal in quarantine. Passengers for Suez were conveyed to Moses' Wells to purge two days' quarantine

div.head: EXPORT OF GUM ARABIC.
div.p: Daring the month of December last, 1,031,614 kilus of gum arabic, valued at LE.23,217, were exported from Egypt. In the same month of 1903 the experts were 574,359 kilos, of the value of L.E.12,967, showing an increase in 1904 of 457,255 kilos, value LE 10,250.

During the year 1904, the exports show increases of 1,989,571 kilos in weight and of LE. 11,394 in amount as compared with 1903, the respective figures being as follows:- 1904, 10,402,054 kilos, value L.E.234,060 ; 1903, 8.412,483 kilos, value L.E.192,666.

Of the above, the export to England and her Mediterranean possessions was 2.220,528 kilos, valno LE 49,960; Germany, 1,740,096 kilos, value LE. 39,159 ; Austria-Hungary, 702,815 kilos, value L.E.15,810 ; France and Algeria, 2,711,811 kilos, value L.B. 60,990; Italy, 286,086 kilos, value LE 6,424 ; Turkey, 12,303 kilos, value L.E.269; America, 1,438, 424 kilos, value L.E.32,364, and to other countries 1,290,992 kilos, value L.E.29,084,

div.head: LORD CROMER'S TRIP.
VISIT TO KENEH.
div.p: Keneh, Saturday. . Lord and Lady Cromer, accompanied by Lady Beatrice Thyone, arrived at keneh by steamer at 1 p.m, to-day. Among those awaiting their arrival were the Moudir, the SubMoudir, all the heads of the Government de partments, the consular agents, omdehs, sheikhs, and a guard of honor.

As the steamer accosted the landing stage, I Lord Cromer stepped out and sbook hands with the Moudir, who introduced a number of those present to his lordship. On Lord Cromer asking if anyone could speak English, the SubMoudir replied in the affirmative, and his lordship proceeded to thank the gathering for their reception, the Sub-Moudir acting as interpreter. Lord Cromer said he regretted he bad no time to visit the town, as he was in al burry to leave for the South

The steamer remained at the landing stage for some time ooaling and at 3.30 sailed for Kous, where the party will stop for the night. On the following morning (Sunday) the steamer will leave at 6 o'olook for Mataang direct and will make another stay there for the night. Erom Mataana the distinguished party proceed to Silwa, from which place they will go to Kom Orabo, where they will remain three hours. Leaving Kom Ombo they will reach Assouan on the afternoon of Tuesday, the 14th | inst. Lord and Lady Cromer expect to be back in Cairo on the 22nd inst.

div.head: THE LATE JUDGE KEILEY.
div.p: The funeral of the late Judge A. M. Kelley, formerly judge of the Mixed Courts of Egypt, who was accidentally killed in the streets of Paris, took place at Notre-Dame on Saturday, February 4. The American Consul-General was present.

Owing to illness, neither the judge's son-inlaw, Captain Hall, nor his daughter were able to be present, but the family was represented by Mr. Arnold Hall and Miss Hall, who came | from England to assist at the ceremony. -

A correspondent writes as followa to the “New York Herald” (Paris) :-I feel that the death of so well- known an American as Judge A. M. Keiley deserves a record. In your edition of Saturday, January 28, I found a short paragraph, ovpied from a French paper, stating that a well-dressed man, about sixty years of age, had been knocked down by a delivery van in the place de la Concorde the day before, and had been carried to the hospital, where he died that night. In his pocket was found a card bearing the name and address of Judge Keiley, 49, Dover-street, Piccadilly-nothing more,

Jndge Keiley was a man well known at home and abroad. He had at various times Atted several publio offices in his native city, vit., Louisville, Ky, and for many years had represented the United States in the Mixed Courts of Egypt. He lived in Alexandria until his wife died, two or three years ago, when he resigned his position and went to London, to be near a married daughter

Judge Keiley was a man of unusual attainments; he knew the classies as he did the alphabet ; not only spoke half a dozen modern languages, but know their literature as well. He know all good things and loved them. He oould tell a story better than the next man, let him tell it never so well, and what is more, could appreciate the point of the other fellow's story. He was liberal, broad-minded, tenderhearted, full of sympathy for suffering : genial and warm-hearted. He was a loyal, staunch friend, and I, who only knew him casually, as it were, feel that I shall not soon look upon his like again.

div.head: A PROPOS DE L'EAU.
div.p: Monsieur le Directeur

de "l'Egyptian Gazette." On fait grand bruit en ce moment, touchant la pollution des eaux que nous vend fort cher "T'Alexandria Water Company Limited" et ce n'est point la première fois que l'on crie que l'eau est contaminée.
Après constatation des faits les services 88nitaires ne préconisent aucun système pour stériliser les conduita et assurer enfin une enu moins chargée de microbes.

Si les dits services poulaient prendre la peine d'analyser l'eau du Mahmoudieh chaque jour et si le résultat de ce petit travail était communiqué au public, celui-ci serait fort surpris d'apprendre quelle quantité considé. rable de microbes il absorbe quotidiennement,
Quant au canal de dérivation qui alimente la Compagnie des Eaux, il est installé dans toutes les conditions requises pour être contaminé en son entier parcours.
En effet, dans tous les alentours du dit canal, il n'y a pas une fosse d'aisances qui soit imperméable et cimentée conformément aux règlements sanitaires.

D'autre part, le service Maritime et Quarantenaire ne fait aucune objection quant à la fourniture de cette eau pour l'approvisionnement des navires et ne prend aucune mesure pour leur procurer de l'eau saine. Le dernier congrès sanitaire de Venise s'est pourtant 00enpé un tantinet de cette question primordiale mais ici, au pays nilotique, la consigne est et sera encore longtemps de dire : Malesch.
De SaixT BONNET. Alexandrie, le 13 février 1905.

div.head: CONDITION. OF HELOUAN. NO GOVERNMENT SUPPORT.
div.p: * Helouan, February 12. An important meeting of the Municipal Commissioners of Helouan has been held at the Gouvernorat under the presidency of H. E. the Governor of Cairo. There were present the Tanzim delegate, Mr. Cartis, the Sanitary Department delegate, Dr. Dryer, and the four elected representative members of the town, M. Felix Suares, Hussein Bey Youssef, Mahmoud Fehmy Pasha, and Dr. A. J. M.| Bentley. | The question of the condition and wanta of the town of Helouan came before the meeting, After some remarks from M. Suares, Hussein Bey Youssef, and Mahmoud Febmy Pasha, on the unsatisfactory condition of the town and the miserable financial dole voted to the Commission, Dr. Bentley addressed the Council as

follows. | Your Excellency, - You may remember that at our last meeting I presented you with & petition from the inhabitants of the town of Helouen aoking that it might be read and considered by th: Council hefore presenting it to the Government for their consideration. This your Excellency did not see fit? to do, and the only course open to the inhabitants was to go with it direct to the chiefs of the Ministries interested, which petition was later on published in several of the newspapers of Bgypt. This petition, I hear on good authority, was not unfavorably received by the heads of tho various departments concerned. The petition, I may call to your mind, dealt with the following points :(i). The railway service ; (ü). The state of the roads and condition of the water supplied for drinking ; (iii). The constitution of the Local Commission ; (iv). The expenditure of the revenue derived from local taxation.--The Railway (i) is now in the possession of the Delta Light Railway Company and they have promised to carry out certain and, we believe, efficient reforms. The matter of the drinking water and the roads (ii) concerns the Tanzim Department. The allocation of the revenue (iv) derived from Helonan is a financial matter and concerns the Ministry of Finance. The carrying out of (ü), which is so urgently required, is

large matter, and it is absolutely impossible to deal with it satisfactorily with the small amount of money allowed to this Commission. (iii The constitution of the Commission is essentially an anomaly s elected partly by public vote to carry out reforms, ithasabsolutely no power to accomplish them. If suggestions are made to the Commission and they are not carried out, the publie regard the failure as being due to its not having the power to im prove, it still has to bear the blame. I propose, therefore, that in the best interests of Helouan. and with a due regard to the dignity of this Council, that the Municipal affairs of the town be placed again in the hands of the Goverament, which alone is able to carry out those reforms so necessary for the well-being of the town. This Commission has doubtless done excellent work in its time, the Tanzim officials connected with it have always been willing to do what they could for the improvement of the town, but owing to the rapidly increasing importance of Helouan and its neigh bourhood, and the urgent and large reforma needed, it is time that the present system, with its very limited powers, should be abolished, and that the municipal affairs should be placed in the hands of the Government, which alone has the power to efficiently carry them out I appeal to your sense of duty not to place any obstacle in the way, but rather to sink all differences and personal feelings for the wellbeing of the town of Helovan, and I further beg to suggest that to facilitate matters this Council should delegate three or more of its members to consult with the Government to ascertain ita views on this matter.

The president, in replying, stated that he had received official information that the Finance Ministry had refused to sanction any further aid to Helovan or to grant money to allow more water for the roads and trees. The tour elected representative members there upon tendered their resignation in a body, as a protest against the Government decision. * Later on they were, however, induced by the president to withdraw their resignations conditionally on his Excellenoy på mising to bring their protest before the proper authorities. They, however, expressed very decided views to his Excellency on the uselessness of holding | further meetings under existing circum stances.

div.head: SHEPHEARD'S SMALL DANCE.
div.p: Last night's small dance at Shepheard's met with the usual success. The restaurant was quite fullat dinner time. Among many others dining there we noticed Mr. and Mrs. Geo. W. | Drexel and party, Mr. B. Johnson and party, including Mr. and Mrs. Thos Walsh and Miss Walsh, Baron von Oppenheim, Baron Tiede mann-Seeheim and family, Mr. Pembroke Jones and family, Mr. and Mrs. Fiedler, Mr. and Mrs. Granville Alexander, Mr. and Mrs. Enn. C. Zervudachi and party, Mr. J. W. Mellor and Miss Mellor, Major Pirie and party, includ ing Major Kenny Herbert, Mr. Carter Wilson and Major Harold ; Baron, Baroness and Miss de Peteghem, Marquis de Corea and Comte Gabriel de Zogheh, Mr. and Mrs. G.T. Rafferty and the Misses Rafferty, Mr. Mrs. and Misses Abbott, Mrs. and the Misses Gelshenen, Prince Lichtenstein, Comte Trautmannsdorf, General and Mrs. von Haewardt, General and Mrs. von Diest, Baron Te-sin, Baron Vogel de Falkenstein, Mrs. Marion Spring and party, Mr., Mrs. and Miss Moss, Mr. and Mrs. Brsley and Mr. Horley, Mr., Mrs., and Miss Pinkerton and Miss Bessie Jordan, Mr. and Mrs. Robinson, eto,

KHEDIVIAL SPORTING CLUB.
3rd WINTER MBETING. - The Kasr, al-Nil Steeplechase will be a Handicap and not as advertised.
KHEDIVIAL YACHT CLUB.
The annual general meeting of the Khedi: vial Yacht Club will be held at the Khedivial Club, Alexandra, ou the 27th inst

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: The King has been pleseed to give and grant unto Robert Lang Anderson, Faq., Manager of the Aboukir Landa Reclamation Company, His Majesty's Royal licence and authority that he may accept and wear the Insignia of the Third Class of the Imperial | Ottoman Order of the Osmanish, conferred | upon him by H.H. the Khedive of Bgypt, authorised by H.I.M. the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered by him to His Highness.
Colonel and Mrs. C. Roadew Barn have left for Egypt, and will join the yacht "Miranda" at the end of March. They do not expect to returú till May.
Baron Angust Twickl is leaving Rome this week for Egypt.
The marriage arranged between M. Henry Thierrard and Mélita, danghter of M. and Mme. S. Caffari, will take place at St. Catherine's Cathedral, Alexandria, on Saturday, 18th inst.

div.head: EXPORT MANIFESTS.
